Posts.Content: Hi Houndly If I was in N VA I would go to John Hopkins in Baltimore. JH is in the top 8 in the nation, many argue it is number one. (I think its #1.) The other ones are in NYC, OH, MN, MO, TX, WA and CA in no particular order. If it is a one shot like surgery with a couple follow ups the drive isn't bad. If it is 2 months of daily radiation you could still get diagnosted at JH (top notch pathology) and get a referral from them to a N VA doc.

Posts.Title: Surgeon in Northern VA?

Posts.Content: I'm assuming it appears to be prostate cancer since this page covers that topic. I used the US News and World Reports survey to select my hospital. My treatment and recovery went very well. I can not say enough about Beth Israel Deaconess in Boston. It is a Harvard Med teaching hospital. The surgeons were Doctor P Chang and Doctor Wagner. With around 1000 De Vinci prostate surgeries to date they are very good and highly recommended. They have patient from all over the world. I had a family member treated by Doctor Samuel Ballon and Stanford Medical Center and definitely recommend him or any referral he may give. As I see it your steps would be: Get a biopsy and pathology report from somewhere near where you live. Select a hospital where you want your procedure and schedule a consultation, also have your pathology samples sent there for a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Hello Goodlife, Dr Walsh's writing on HT use is the current thinking but it must be taken in context. HT can be used in several settings such as: - concurrent with radiation therapy that is the primary treatment or adjuvant or salvage radiation after surgery when treating what is believed to be local disease. - to control the disease once it becomes systemic. It is this second setting that Dr Walsh is referring to. The argument is do we use HT to keep the PSA value low and accept the heavy side effects for what could be years, or do we delay HT until the disease is systemic and there are Mets. If the time to the end phase and death is the same, he argues, why not skip the long period of side effects from early HT? If I'm reading your husbands signature right and the nodes detected by MRI are within the prostate and not bone or elsewhere, you fall into a completely different category. With G9 PC the chance of re-occurrence by 5 years, even with primary and salvage treatment can be in the range of 45% to 75% which are not great odds. Some doctors and several trials are trying HT or HT + Chemo pre-surgery to improve these odds for G8-G10 patients. The initial data suggests there is merit to this approach. If this is the case for your husband then his doctor is being very aggressive and is at the the cutting edge of today's PC treatment. Some on this site often suggest "throwing everything at the PC including the kitchen sink" right from the beginning. This sounds like the path your doctor is taking. I started my journey 7/13, at that time I did not see this aggressive approach in the literature, by the time I did see it I had already had my RALP. I'm doing fine so far but would have gone down the path of HT+Chemo pre-surgery had I known it was an option. Best wishes

Medicine has progressed some since 1999. I'd imagine the tables etc will be more favorable a decade or more from now when many of us will be contributing data points. Sites like this didn't exists back then with all of us trading knowledge, this alone would bend the curves a little it would seem.

Posts.Title: I'm Confused by Han and Partin Table Stats

Posts.Content: Yes, that is them. I used 2 pkgs and 1 of the mediums. 172 total. I still have most of the mediums left so I used 140. The catheter tube is about 3/16" OD and goes from the penis to the bag. The bag has a connector so you can disconnect it to replace it. The bags come in various sizes. I used the large one I left the hospital with from start to finish. It has a cap on it so you can empty it into the toilet. With the garter I could get sweat pants over it with no problem for the trip home from the hospital and to go out of the house. They make a leg bag, it is smaller so you could wear slacks over it. Where the tube goes into the penis gets sore and infection is a risk. They will give ointment for this. You will see blood cots and other stuff in the bag and the urine may be red at times. All of this is normal. I went to the office on day 8 (the day after the catheter was out) for a couple of hours and we went out to an old Inn for Thanksgiving the next day. On the following Monday I (day 13) was back at work from around 9:30 to 4 or 5PM. I had a cushion when I was at the computer but found I did better standing at a lab bench. I was not embarrassed to ask for a hand if I had to move anything over 10 lbs. By week 3 I was back to full time but I have a lot of flexibility. I could set, walk around, stand or just leave if I wanted to. Key for you is to stay hydrated, nourished, get plenty of rest, and get up for a short shuffle around the house.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for recovery

Posts.Content: You should be fine. The hard week will be the first due to the catheter. Every several hours it has the be emptied. The bed or sofa are both fine. You will want to get up and walk around the house very hour to avoid clots. The regular toilet is all you need, with the catheter #1 is taken care of and you'll be lucky to have a BM before day 3 or 4. They will prescribe a stool softener like Colace or similar, be sure to take it just as they say. Stock up on non diet jello, Gatorade, maybe Ensure. Something like Gatorade will keep your electrolytes balanced, keep you hydrated, and get you some sugar for energy should you not feel like getting up and fixing something to eat. Until your bowls start working you are not going to be eating Hot Pockets and the like. You will want a low residual diet, no whole gains, seeds, nuts, raw veggies, etc. Get off the narcotics like Percocet because it causes constipation to continue. NO alcohol while on narcotics. While on Percocet make sure you do not leave the stove on and go to sleep. Take care not to snag the catheter on anything, it doesn't take a lot to pull it out. Keep the bag lower that the bladder so nothing runs back into you. I suggest buying a garter belt to hold the bag. They are on Amazon or at a local med supply. It is much more comfortable than the tape to the leg set you leave the hospital with. Also loose fitting sweat or basket ball pants are handy when going out. Realize they actually cut the urethra to remove the prostate and reattach it to the bladder (Yikes!). This is mostly why they say take it easy and no lifting. It is also why they say no straining on the toilet. There is nothing like a blast like a tee shirt cannon from the rear due to too much fiber before the system is starting to move again or too much Colace. You can do some real damage, and it hurts. Once the catheter is out you will be over the hump and able to go shopping, drop in on friends, go out to dinner, etc. Do not drive if still on narcotics. You will need a soft cushion to set on for the first 3-4 weeks, hard surfaces, bar stools, bicycles, etc are out. You are better off with Depends pads you put in your briefs than the one piece underwear. The heavy ones will hold a full bladder and not leak. They fit in your pocket, and you do not need to get undressed to yank it out and put in a new one.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for recovery

Posts.Content: You should be fine. The hard week will be the first due to the catheter. Every several hours it has the be emptied. The bed or sofa are both fine. You will want to get up and walk around the house very hour to avoid clots. The regular toilet is all you need, with the catheter #1 is taken care of and you'll be lucky to have a BM before day 3 or 4. They will prescribe a stool softener like Colace or similar, be sure to take it just as they say. Stock up on non diet jello, Gatorade, maybe Ensure. Something like Gatorade will keep your electrolytes balanced, keep you hydrated, and get you some sugar for energy should you not feel like getting up and fixing something to eat. Until your bowls start working you are not going to be eating Hot Pockets and the like. You will want a low residual diet, no whole gains, seeds, nuts, raw veggies, etc. Get off the narcotics like Percocet because it causes constipation to continue. NO alcohol while on narcotics. While on Percocet make sure you do not leave the stove on and go to sleep. Take care not to snag the catheter on anything, it doesn't take a lot to pull it out. Keep the bag lower that the bladder so nothing runs back into you. I suggest buying a garter belt to hold the bag. They are on Amazon or at a local med supply. It is much more comfortable than the tape to the leg set you leave the hospital with. Also loose fitting sweat or basket ball pants are handy when going out. Realize they actually cut the urethra to remove the prostate and reattach it to the bladder (Yikes!). This is mostly why they say take it easy and no lifting. It is also why they say no straining on the toilet. There is nothing like a blast like a tee shirt cannon from the rear due to too much fiber before the system is starting to move again or too much Colace. You can do some real damage, and it hurts. Once the catheter is out you will be over the hump and able to go shopping, drop in on friends, go out to dinner, etc. Do not drive if still on narcotics. You will need a soft cushion to set on for the first 3-4 weeks, hard surfaces, bar stools, bicycles, etc are out. You are better off with Depends pads you put in your briefs than the one piece underwear. The heavy ones will hold a full bladder and not leak. They fit in your pocket, and you do not need to get undressed to yank it out and put in a new one.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for recovery

Posts.Content: Yes, that is them. I used 2 pkgs and 1 of the mediums. 172 total. I still have most of the mediums left so I used 140. The catheter tube is about 3/16" OD and goes from the penis to the bag. The bag has a connector so you can disconnect it to replace it. The bags come in various sizes. I used the large one I left the hospital with from start to finish. It has a cap on it so you can empty it into the toilet. With the garter I could get sweat pants over it with no problem for the trip home from the hospital and to go out of the house. They make a leg bag, it is smaller so you could wear slacks over it. Where the tube goes into the penis gets sore and infection is a risk. They will give ointment for this. You will see blood cots and other stuff in the bag and the urine may be red at times. All of this is normal. I went to the office on day 8 (the day after the catheter was out) for a couple of hours and we went out to an old Inn for Thanksgiving the next day. On the following Monday I (day 13) was back at work from around 9:30 to 4 or 5PM. I had a cushion when I was at the computer but found I did better standing at a lab bench. I was not embarrassed to ask for a hand if I had to move anything over 10 lbs. By week 3 I was back to full time but I have a lot of flexibility. I could set, walk around, stand or just leave if I wanted to. Key for you is to stay hydrated, nourished, get plenty of rest, and get up for a short shuffle around the house.

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: Hello Andreag08, I'm sorry to hear the news about your brother. As I deal with PC my sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer. I'm more worried about her than myself. The initial numbers places him in the High Grade PC group which means a cure is less likely and reoccurrence even after an initial cure is more likely. The results of the bone scan and CT or MRI are important to get a total picture as they will show if the PC has advanced to the bones etc. Either way it will need to be treated based on these numbers. PC is fairly slow to spread, he has weeks to months to chose his treatment and medical team that can give him the best outcome. It is likely they will re-evaluate the biopsy samples which may change the G scores. You can gain a sense of the time line by reviewing the signatures of the members in this forum.

Posts.Content: Hi, I was OK for the first 4 or so weeks, then the bowel issues started. I though of eating as loading the cannon. I mentioned it to the nurse and RO. They gave me a low residual diet to follow and it really helped. The diet is everything I normally wouldn't eat like white bread and processed foods. No nuts, whole grains, fruit with seeds, etc. If it is healthy, don't eat it. It is their policy to have patients stay on their normal diet until they report a problem. They also suggested Imodium but only if it was necessary. I never used it. The last couple of weeks it mostly cleared up and by my last or two of 9 weeks I was safely back on my regular diet.

Posts.Content: Hello Mary, Given his numbers there is a lot of reason for optimism. One of the top 5 centers for robotic-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy (RALP) is John Hopkins in Baltimore. If you are coming from the south it is an extra hour, but I sure wouldn't drive past it to get to DC. My experience: I chose to drive 1.5 hours to Boston for my procedure, I was discharged at 3PM the following day and it turn into over a three hour drive home in worst than typical Boston rush hour traffic. Setting wasn't too bad but the pot holes and stop and go portion was painful. They actually cut the urethra and re-attach it to the bladder, also the wall of the rectum is thinned to some extent. A really hard stop or collision could do some serious damage. I would not do 3 hours again. I returned to the hospital 7 days later to have my catheter removed. The day the catheter was removed I was driving, spent some time at the office and felt pretty good. I was off narcotics and only taking Tylenol. My next appointment was 3 months later for the follow up. I called my GP to order my blood test which was done in a local lab, the visit with the surgeon was a 15 to 20 minute office discussion. For my 6 and 9 month I had the local PSA test results sent to him and we had a short telephone call to discuss the results. The hospital had a on-line "Patient Site" where I could see all my labs, Doctor reports, and communicate via secure e-mail. For the few questions I had he or his PA answered my e-mail within hours. I selected a hospital highly ranked by US News and World reports for "patient outcomes" as "significantly better than expected". Outcomes relate to infections, lung and heart issues, and other such problems and not cancer cure rates. My surgical team had to have completed over 300 procedures, period. They had over 1000. Others have written the importance of having over 200-300 procedures. There are several studies that demonstrate why. Here are some numbers from a study titled "The learning curve for reducing complications of robotic-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy by a single surgeon": Blood transfusion incidence was 8%, 4%, 2% and 0% in Groups I, II, III and IV, respectively. Complication rates were 18%, 12%, 18% and 0% in Groups I, II, III and IV, respectively. Major complications (grade III-IV) were 6%, 2%, 4% and 0% in Groups I, II, III and IV, respectively. The groups were 1-50, 51-100,101-150, and 151-200 procedures. You can search nih dot gov for the title or 21050363 to see the report abstract. It's short and easy to read. This is only one of many with the same finding. I would find a good surgeon within 2 hours of home or less, or plan on staying near the medical center for the week. The Stay America, Embassy Suites, or others often offer special weekly rates for patients for comfortable suites. The American Cancer Society and others arrange stays in various properties including private homes at very low rates to free in some areas. I wish you well.

This is only one of many with the same finding. I would find a good surgeon within 2 hours of home or less, or plan on staying near the medical center for the week. The Stay America, Embassy Suites, or others often offer special weekly rates for patients for comfortable suites. The American Cancer Society and others arrange stays in various properties including private homes at very low rates to free in some areas. I wish you well.

Posts.Title: Questions about Traveling for Treatment and Getting Local Care

Posts.Content: Michael's question on brachytherapy or isotopes is a good one. Radiation Therapy isn't nuclear, it is x-rays which are gone the instant the machine cuts off. I traveled a lot including DEN while still wearing pads and to my surprise never had a problem getting through the full body scanner. I have a mesh from an old hernia that they find every time. Shaww is right about TSA Precheck. I've never signed up for it but 3 of every 4 trips I get it. It is like the old days; belt, jacket, and shoes on, computer left in the case, and a simple walk thru metal detector. Much shorter lines also.

Posts.Title: Opting out of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Hello Gail and Cliff, Your post hit a cord because I'm weighting the merits of HT while on RT and very interested in what inputs you get and which direction you take. The guidelines are a total of 2-3 years on HT when on adjuvant or salvage RT. I'm going to ask my MO and RO about a compromise of staying on HT for 3 months post RT. Also the longer you are on HT the longer it takes for T to recover and at some point it never recovers. I want to understand this better. I have been on Lupron since Nov/14 and get my first IMRT this Thursday. While I'm completely active I feel the effects of HT daily. It's the impact to motivation and a short cardio "hump" (a pinch of short breath and higher heart rate) to get pass when I go from idle to active. Once moving I'm fine. Like others I notice that while I've stepped up my weight lifting I've had to reduce the weights with time. The jury is out on cardiac issues but it seems to me living like this for 2-3 years has to take a toll in that area. My MO said RT kills distant cancer when HT is used. Walsh's book mentions cell suicide when RT and HT are used together. In another place he says the combo is very effective for high grade cancers after RP. Here is a graph in a paper comparing RT with RT+HT. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/arti...5/figure/fig2/ The graph is striking. The whole paper is at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3235425/ There are several paper on RP + SRT with and with out HT. HT definitely improves the odds of not recurring at 5 years and even more so at 10 years. HMS

Posts.Title: Opting out of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: The end of a 3 month Lupron cycles was coincident with my last radiation treatment yesterday. I had an appointment with my MO for my next 3 month Lupron shot, or so I thought. He was not inclined to do another shot. I had read HT for 12-18 months after RT was beneficial and standard for G8-G10s. He agreed IF I had a prostate and RT was my primary treatment. Since I had surgery first and this was salvage RT I do not have a prostate so HT for longer than 6 months total was questionable. I tested the case that my SRT was started 2 months late (4 months after HT started) and the 3 months of the last shot ended at the same day as my SRT, I would not have much overlap of HT and SRT. He agreed there might be merit to one more 3 month shot to ensure coverage while my RT was doing its thing. (RT doesn't "kill" the PC cells, it prevents them from dividing and they die over days to weeks.) So I got the shot, and it is my last one. Reading several PubMed papers this morning I found several saying 6 months of HT concurrent with SRT may be of benefit but longer term was not associated with any additional increase in prostate cancer-specific survival. It sounds like 6 months of HT is enough for those undergoing SRT.

The guidelines are a total of 2-3 years on HT when on adjuvant or salvage RT. I'm going to ask my MO and RO about a compromise of staying on HT for 3 months post RT. Also the longer you are on HT the longer it takes for T to recover and at some point it never recovers. I want to understand this better. I have been on Lupron since Nov/14 and get my first IMRT this Thursday. While I'm completely active I feel the effects of HT daily. It's the impact to motivation and a short cardio "hump" (a pinch of short breath and higher heart rate) to get pass when I go from idle to active. Once moving I'm fine. Like others I notice that while I've stepped up my weight lifting I've had to reduce the weights with time. The jury is out on cardiac issues but it seems to me living like this for 2-3 years has to take a toll in that area. My MO said RT kills distant cancer when HT is used. Walsh's book mentions cell suicide when RT and HT are used together. In another place he says the combo is very effective for high grade cancers after RP. Here is a graph in a paper comparing RT with RT+HT. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/arti...5/figure/fig2/ The graph is striking. The whole paper is at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3235425/ There are several paper on RP + SRT with and with out HT. HT definitely improves the odds of not recurring at 5 years and even more so at 10 years. HMS
Posts.Signature: July 2012 DRE normal but the test was shallow and quick, no PSA May 2013 Doctor retired, new Doctor May 2013 PSA 5.7, DRE with significant hard lump left side July 2013 Biopsy 10 of 12 cores scored 4/4, CT abdomen, bone scan both negative Nov 2013 DaVinci prostatectomy at Beth Israel Deaconess Boston, non-nerve sparing - surgeon went wide, age 63 seminal duct, urethra, and 3 of 26 lymph nodes positive, Gleason upgraded to 4/5 =9 Post op exams 3/14 <.01, 6/14 .01, 9/14 .05, 11/14 .1 Lupron injec 11/14 30 day, 12/15 90 day, 3/15 90 day, 6/15 90 day (T heads up after 9/15) With HT exams 12/14 <.1, 3/15 <.1 Salvage IMRT 3/31 - 6/4/2015 34 X 2GY= 68GY 6/2015 PSA <.1 (still on HT) 9/2015 PSA <.1 (still on HT) 12/2015 PSA <0.01 no HT, T normal

Posts.Title: Opting out of Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: It can be frustrating, most of us would be out of a job if our error rate was similar. Your last test at <.1 was standard sensitivity. You might want to switch to high sensisitivity. I went from <.01 to .01 to .05 and finally .1 at the end of the first when I started radiation. My last 3 are once again <.01 over the past year. Using the standard test I would have lost a year not knowing what was going on. As a G7 your odds at not recurring post surgery are better than mine were but there is something nice about a <0.01

Posts.Title: UGHY! Why Me!

Posts.Content: Hello Brahms, Creekrat finished his radiation therapy (RT) a week plus ago and I finish tomorrow. Without going back more than a week you can find the week by week logs we have both left on this site. As treatments go it wasn't bad at all. Have they started Lupron or other hormone treatment (HT) ahead of RT? With a G9 it is pretty much the standard and has been shown to make a real difference long term. HT is worst than RT. On surgery I had 12 of 16 cores that were 10% to 90% involved with 4/5=G9 and still had surgery. Of the 5 med centers I interviewed only one said "you will need radiation anyway so there is no point having surgery". I wanted surgery so I picked one of the others.... I'm happy with surgery and then radiation. Having had both now I'll say radiation is the easier of the two and has a similar cure rate with fewer side effects.

Posts.Content: Moderation in all things. I drink 3oz of 100% pomegranate juice with a meal every day. It is high in sugars and calories. I've done it for years, and still ended up with G 4/5=9 with positive everything except mets. Pomegranate juice is a mild beta blocker lowering heart rate and at 67mg/oz of potassium helps a little to counter our daily overdose of sodium.

Posts.Title: Pomegranate juice lower PSA, I think

Posts.Content: Hi Gina, I've seen many med journal paper on the topic such as this short one: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22695242 (2012) Skipping to the conclusion they write: "most markers have not been prospectively validated for providing useful prognostic or predictive information or improvement upon clinicopathologic parameters already in use." There are other papers covering Genomes and a whole host of other markers that are long and detailed but they all end with "the process appears to have merit, send more money for research." Here is another paper. It is good, but long. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3214657/ Maybe someone else here has had better luck fishing for info. HMS

Posts.Title: Decipher Genome Test?

Posts.Content: Hello MLS, Where you are headed to the office after removing the catheter specifically to check for retention you won't have any problems. It sounds like a good plan. The ultrasound test is quick and easy. HMS
Posts.Title: Weekend getaway turned into ER visit and catheter for urinary retention, now what?

Posts.Content: Hello Davis, Once Chuck chimes in I'm sure he'll add it is written a 3+4 often behaves like a 3+3 meaning that it does not travel beyond the prostate. A 90% chance of not needing RT means a 90% chance of not having a re-occurrence which is very good. It is likely that a re-occurrence would be related to the positive margin which is to say local, and very treatable with RT with a cure the likely outcome. Your first "tell" will be your first PSA usually at 3 months, personally I would get the ultra-sensitive test, when it comes back as "undetectable" you will know you are probably in the clear. With each subsequent test your confidence will build. So as Shaww said, your glass is 90% full. You have a lot of reasons to be optimistic that you are cured, but you need to keep an eye on it so you do not miss an opportunity to wack it again if necessary. Some argue against the ultra-sensitive test as TMI but in three month increments I went from <.01 to .01 to .05 to .1 at 12 months. With a standard test I would have seen <.1 at each test until the last test which would have been .1 (note that I was a G4+5 with positive everything so no one was surprised) I wish you the best. HMS

Posts.Title: I need a Glass-Half-Full session here:

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MLS Husband will clip one end of catheter and remove himself on Thursday I'm truly sorry this happened to you both, especially before a few days away. Emergency catheterization is one of my worst fears. I have not been through it. I was given the option of removing my catheter after prostate surgery to avoid a long drive to the hospital. I was not interested in this option. You are going to be at a medical facility Thursday afternoon for the ultra sound, I would make a earlier appointment and have them remove the catheter with a back flush. They use a large syringe to push water into the bladder just before they pull the catheter out. All of this water should come gushing out of the penis as soon as the catheter is removed. I have been through this, it does not hurt at all. They do not expect a problem if they want him to do it at home and you will be going to the clinic thereafter anyway. But should there be a problem he will be standing in front of the Doctor that can address it. I'm not a Doctor or any type of medical person. I'm just a guy that probably has a irrational fear of catheters. I wish you the best. HMS

Posts.Title: Oh Blah....part deux.

Posts.Content: Hello Davis, Once Chuck chimes in I'm sure he'll add it is written a 3+4 often behaves like a 3+3 meaning that it does not travel beyond the prostate. A 90% chance of not needing RT means a 90% chance of not having a re-occurrence which is very good. It is likely that a re-occurrence would be related to the positive margin which is to say local, and very treatable with RT with a cure the likely outcome. Your first "tell" will be your first PSA usually at 3 months, personally I would get the ultra-sensitive test, when it comes back as "undetectable" you will know you are probably in the clear. With each subsequent test your confidence will build. So as Shaww said, your glass is 90% full. You have a lot of reasons to be optimistic that you are cured, but you need to keep an eye on it so you do not miss an opportunity to wack it again if necessary. Some argue against the ultra-sensitive test as TMI but in three month increments I went from <.01 to .01 to .05 to .1 at 12 months. With a standard test I would have seen <.1 at each test until the last test which would have been .1 (note that I was a G4+5 with positive everything so no one was surprised) I wish you the best. HMS

Posts.Title: I need a Glass-Half-Full session here:

Posts.Content: Lupron causes fatigue, in trials it was seen in 75% of the patients. My guess the nurse is working for the pay check without digging into what she is really doing. I do not know of an alternative to Lupron, but hopefully someone on here will. I've only been on it for 5 months. I'm active and in very good health but it has effected my strength even though I have been lifting weights more than before and it has slowed me down a bit. I think there is another aspect to it that effects me. Where I would work a 12 hour day, have dinner, and then go to the workshop till midnight I'm happy to watch TV or set and read a book after work. Its not that I'm tired, I'm just not drawn to projects like I was. My wife likes me just being around. It think the lack of testosterone has taken the conquering warrior out of me. Like there is more to libido than just the obvious. With all of that said I wonder how much of your Dad's issues are fatigue, and how much is loss of strength and motivation. I know I have to generate motivation to keep me busy or I'd just rest which would not be good. One motivation is having clients, this forces me to prepare and be somewhere on time. By motivation I mean something I have to do, not want to do.

Posts.Title: Made my choice today

Posts.Content: Hello Mike, creekrat and I both posted a weekly log of our RT on this site from March through June of this year. Like many others it was pretty much side effect free. Creekrat's was primary treatment and mine was salvage which is closer to your case. Other than loose bowls in week 6 which was cured with a change of diet the only negative was having a daily appointment to keep for 8 weeks. Now 5 months after my last treatment I'm symptom and side effect free. Others have posted good advise. To repeat much of it: A PSA= 8 after RP says there was PC left behind. While ADT lowers your PSA there is a chance the PC can mature to being ADT tolerate and find its way to distance sites in the back ground. The hard part is determining if the PC is still local to the prostate bed. If it is SRT will help, if isn't then there is no point doing SRT. Various bone scans can see larger metastatic tumors which would definitely say it is not local. The problem is when the scans are negative but there may be mico-metastasis that can not be seen with CT or MRIs. Whether it is local and warrants SRT or not becomes a judgement call for the MO and RO. If PSA is increasing right after surgery and there were positive margins they attribute the increase to the margins and assume (hope) the PC is local, as they did in my case, and start SRT. As time goes on after RP this judgement call becomes more difficult. you need a really good MO and RO to make the right call. If there is a shot that the PC is local and SRT will kill it you need to take it. At 9 months on Lupron I was really starting to notice muscle loss and other issues, I'm glad to be off it while hoping my PSA remains un-detectable as my T returns to normal. So far, so good. My bone scan was sodium fluoride PET/CT.

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Questions, and should I see a Urologist or Oncologist after surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Joe, I'm truly sorry to hear you face this dilemma. I understand avoiding any treatments that impact quality of life in the near term. A biopsy is not a treatment. It is just a test that take 15 minutes in the Urologist office that will give you needed information. The hardest part is waiting for the results. The information gained from the test is useful for managing PCa if present, and planning your future while minimizing the possible impact on your caregiver. You may have a infection that has enlarged the prostate and also my impact urination. If it is PCa 80% of the cases never have symptoms and do not require treatment. High grade cases can often be cured with invasive procedures or progression delayed by years with drugs. The very rare (<1%) forms result in death within a year, maybe 2. I the unlikely event that it is high grade PCa strategies to manage the symptoms can be developed while minimizing QoL issues, but you need the information.....

Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: Hello Joe, I'm truly sorry to hear you face this dilemma. I understand avoiding any treatments that impact quality of life in the near term. A biopsy is not a treatment. It is just a test that take 15 minutes in the Urologist office that will give you needed information. The hardest part is waiting for the results. The information gained from the test is useful for managing PCa if present, and planning your future while minimizing the possible impact on your caregiver. You may have a infection that has enlarged the prostate and also my impact urination. If it is PCa 80% of the cases never have symptoms and do not require treatment. High grade cases can often be cured with invasive procedures or progression delayed by years with drugs. The very rare (<1%) forms result in death within a year, maybe 2. Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: Hello Bee, There is reason for optimism that a zero was slipped, it happen to me. Let's hope it is .03 but if it is truly a 0.3 then SRT with concurrent HRT sooner than later is likely. The somewhat iffy pathology report suggested there may have been positive margins. If cells were left behind they could be the source of the .3. It is better to have a local disease that is treatable, and possibly curable, with SRT due to positive margins than to have a systemic disease that has spread to distant places. Both Creekrat and I each posted radiation logs on this forum in March and updated them weekly through May. Creek's was a primary treatment and mine was SRT with 34 sessions. The good news is with SRT they normally only do HRT for 6 months. A quick read shows that it wasn't a bad experience at all. HMS

Posts.Title: 1st PSA 3 months post RALP = 0.3. What to do?

Posts.Content: My details are below. Nothing was spared in surgery, erections will be back once I get an implant. It is likely your DH will or has regain his naturally. After a year I started Lupron. I have been on it since Nov. I get hot once or twice a day. I do not notice it coming on, my shoulder and face are all of a sudden hot. It is brief. That is the only symptom for me. My wife and I are as intimate as ever. It is interesting once erections are off the table the tell tale sign is also gone. It is no longer game on when it is up and completely over when it goes down and a non-starter if it never goes up. Many guys write about multiple and better orgasms. That's my experience. Lupron will cause the loss of erections in most men, so it's no longer game on or off. It takes longer to reach orgasm but that works to my wife's advantage and when it is better for her it's better for me. In short, I need her more and closer than pre PC.

Posts.Title: What does loss of libido truly mean?

Posts.Content: I took a pair of the depends briefs to the catheter removal appointment and wore them home. Never again. I switched to pads in my Jockeys that evening. The heavy ones will hold a bladder full with no leaks. They fit in a pocket. You can snatch them out and replace them with your pants on. It seems a lot of guys are dry laying down from day one, including me, now getting vertical and to the head is a challenge.... One package of the heavy and 2 of the moderate pads got me through. 210 total. I still have a 1/2 pack left. Watch the catheter. The nurse caught mine and gave it a yank getting into the car. A week later the PA pull the shelf out on the examining bench snagging it, pulling it out a bit. I was really amazed how easily the Dr pulled it out. Your urethra was cut in two and reattached to the bladder (yikes). No lifting, straining, bar stools or bicycles. They sent me home with its straps taped to my leg. One day 3 the wife picked up a garter at a med supply, it was a big improvement. How it lasted a week I don't know. Make sure you have sweat or warm up pants handy. The baggy light poly ones are best. Get off the narcotics sooner than later, they cause constipation. I was on Tylenol at day 3. No straining, even down there, keep popping the Colace or similar stool softener they will give you. Get up and walk a loop around the house once an hour. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 2 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Stephen You can see for my signature below I have some of the same issues but with 4/5 G9. PSA was 0 at month 3 and had only risen to 0.1 in a year. My RO and MO are optimistic that RT with HT will give me a cure or very long time to occurrence. Being at G7, even with the 4/3, you have good reason to be optimistic. Ajuvant RT is often started at 6 months to let you recover from the RALP. Where-ever you are at with incontinence and ED is frozen when you start RT. If he was planning to start RT it would begin with an office visit. It would be followed by a planning session (a MRI used to make a map for the RT machine), and a week or so later the start of 38-45 daily treatments. They may well suggest HT which would start 2 months before RT. What part of the country are you in? There may be a highly regarded RT center much closer to you. HMS

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: There are many documented reports at NIH/Pubmeds as follows: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26399602 "Despite less favourable tumour characteristics, patients receiving SRT and ADT demonstrated improved b-PFS, and in particular, patients with PSA levels >0.2 ng/ml benefited from additional ADT." http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21645976 "Adjuvant ADT results in a significant improvement in clinical progression and PCSM across multiple definitions of high-risk disease even with dose-escalated EBRT." You only get one shot at this. Lupron or similar for just 4-6 months can be tolerated. He will get hot flashes starting at 30 days, they spring up and are gone quickly, and his initiative to do most things will be reduced. My MO assured me that bone loss, cardiac issues, growing breasts, etc are not an issue in 4-6 moths of use. Time goes quickly, 6 months from now he will be past it's affects and and have a better shot at being cured. Anything that may help avoid the PC becoming metastatic should be considered. I would opt for a 30 day injection and if all goes well by an additional 90 day injection.

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=ddayglo;293763]I'm wondering if there's any way to determine if the radiation is not 100% effective, then as quickly as possible take out the "big guns" - HT -- to add to the fight. RT doesn't outright kill all of the PC, it keeps the cells from growing, and they die. Many of them die after the last RT treatment. PC is in the blood, a path to suitable bone is not a given, it is difficult. HT impacts the PC cells everywhere including in the blood making it even more difficult to survive the search for bone or other sites that can host them. If you wait until the PSA starts to rise after RT you are dealing with systemic PC for which currently there is no cure. In short you have a shot at killing the ones that have left the nest but have yet to find a home with HT. The Gleason 4 cells are possibly at or past the line between needing testosterone and being able to survive without it. Leave them be and let them progress (it is not a given they will) until they are testosterone independent and you are in trouble. The alternative is to cut their testosterone supply via HT and hopefully they will starve to death. This leaves one on the fence, 9 months of tolerable discomfort (1% have serious side effects) of HT which might not be required, versus a chance of avoiding or delaying a metastatic disease. If it was Gleason 3 cells remaining post RP just zap them and skip the HT. The circulating cells will likely die outside the prostate area on their own.

Posts.Content: After a RALP and salvage IMRT I'm 3 months beyond my last Lupron shot wearing off. My testosterone is back to normal at 443 and my PSA is <0.01 and I haven't had a hot flash in a month. For the newbies having testosterone AND a undetectable PSA is the good news. As a G=4/5=9 with positive everything including lymph nodes at surgery it is great news at the end of a long journey. I've graduated to being a non-patient and turned in my ID card today. For now the only thing on the medical calendar are quarterly PSA checks with my local GP. Hopefully I'll get to enjoy this gift for a long while.

And some mention the suction hose. I'm interested in which process your clinic used.

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: I have seen the reports and they look favorable. A couple of the studies were terminated early due to the success rate and the desire to move the control group onto the protocol. I'm aware of a local Phase three study where they are combining Taxotere, Luprone and Salvage RT for post RP patients with G8-G10 PC like to reoccur. I considered it. It will be months before the study starts and I did not want to wait. I was also concerned about the side effects of chemo but several people on this forums say they were not bad.

Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: After a RALP and salvage IMRT I'm 3 months beyond my last Lupron shot wearing off. My testosterone is back to normal at 443 and my PSA is <0.01 and I haven't had a hot flash in a month. For the newbies having testosterone AND a undetectable PSA is the good news. As a G=4/5=9 with positive everything including lymph nodes at surgery it is great news at the end of a long journey. I've graduated to being a non-patient and turned in my ID card today. For now the only thing on the medical calendar are quarterly PSA checks with my local GP. Hopefully I'll get to enjoy this gift for a long while.

Posts.Title: Do testicles grow with age?

Posts.Content: Hi Georgia Gal, Personally I'm biased toward surgery, even if has to be followed up with Radiation. Post surgery when the Pathologist gets the prostate you know 99% where you stand. For the 1% you can rely on the post-op PSA. At the three month test it should be undetectable and stay there. One thing I want to add was concerning ED. In the worst case if non-nerve sparring surgery is needed, ED is permanent. But orgasms are at least the same with many men on this site reporting an improvement. The "one (maybe two) and you are done" is gone for some reason. There are several ways to deal with the ED but once accomplished sex can be better than before. I would shoot for nerve sparring surgery. For G 3+4 and lower it as been shown to be safe, for G8-G10 the surgeons goes wide and takes it all. G 4+3 is a bit more gray. It sounds like you have a good surgeon and at a great med center, I would go with the surgeon on this one.

Posts.Content: Hello Marve, The doctors answer is like what was typical in the USA in the 1960s and before, but not in 2015. Posts.Title: Why radiation after surgery???

Posts.Content: Hello Stephen You can see for my signature below I have some of the same issues but with 4/5 G9. PSA was 0 at month 3 and had only risen to 0.1 in a year. My RO and MO are optimistic that RT with HT will give me a cure or very long time to occurrence. Being at G7, even with the 4/3, you have good reason to be optimistic. Ajuvant RT is often started at 6 months to let you recover from the RALP. Where-ever you are at with incontinence and ED is frozen when you start RT. If he was planning to start RT it would begin with an office visit. It would be followed by a planning session (a MRI used to make a map for the RT machine), and a week or so later the start of 38-45 daily treatments. They may well suggest HT which would start 2 months before RT. What part of the country are you in? There may be a highly regarded RT center much closer to you. HMS

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: There are many documented reports at NIH/Pubmeds as follows: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26399602 "Despite less favourable tumour characteristics, patients receiving SRT and ADT demonstrated improved b-PFS, and in particular, patients with PSA levels >0.2 ng/ml benefited from additional ADT." http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21645976 "Adjuvant ADT results in a significant improvement in clinical progression and PCSM across multiple definitions of high-risk disease even with dose-escalated EBRT." You only get one shot at this. Lupron or similar for just 4-6 months can be tolerated. He will get hot flashes starting at 30 days, they spring up and are gone quickly, and his initiative to do most things will be reduced. My MO assured me that bone loss, cardiac issues, growing breasts, etc are not an issue in 4-6 moths of use. Time goes quickly, 6 months from now he will be past it's affects and and have a better shot at being cured. Anything that may help avoid the PC becoming metastatic should be considered. I would opt for a 30 day injection and if all goes well by an additional 90 day injection.

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: I 2nd Michael's Well Done! Any time it is caught early (G6) it is great news. Get a head start on the Kegels just by doing a set of 4-5 each time you go. By September you'll be set. Most of us started a week before surgery. Several weeks before D-Day hit Amazon for a Folly catheter bag garter, it is a lot more comfortable than the tape to the leg job you leave the hospital with. Have the conversation with the Uro/surgeon dealing with penile rehab before surgery, twist his arm to get a plan and get prescriptions or whatever at cath removal. Post surgery it is easy for this to slip. Let it go too long and you'll come up short, and might endure added pain.

Posts.Title: Meeting with surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gailannr I was wondering if someone could explain what the results of the Testosterone Serum <10 L means? I am assuming the L means low but not sure. Thanks, Gail 10 ng/dL (nano gram per deci Liter). 10 nano grams per 1/10 Liter is low. "Normal" is around 500. nmol/L (nano mole per liter) is sometimes used but "normal" is above 11.1 nmol/L on this scale which rules this scale out given the HT where nothing is normal...

Posts.Title: Meeting with surgeon

Posts.Content: Hello civictim, If you have PC, it is circulating in the blood with or without surgery. In a previous post I included a NIH PubMeds paper on this. The importance of PC outside the prostate, such as in lymph nodes, is two fold 1.) is it suggests the PC has mutated to the point it can live "away from home". That is why there is some concern with positive margins, a bit more with seminal ducts, and even more concern with lymph node invasion. Each shows a greater degree of independence from the prostate and therefore more likely to become metastatic to bone etc. and 2.) there is still cancer in the body. This is where the Gleason score becomes important. G6 and down the PC is typically too immature to live outside the prostate and simply dies, G7 it is a maybe, and G8-G10 it generally assumed it can live beyond the prostate. That is why the recurrence rate is high even when the prostate is removed or radiated with G8-10, even if everything comes back negative from pathology. On surgery with High grade PC: With a G4/4=8 at biopsy I did not have a problem finding a surgeon at major PC centers to do a RALP, the RO sat through the meeting and agreed with the approach. I had 3 options for my RALP including JH. The reason they supported a RP is not every cancer cell finds a nice piece of bone to start a successful colony in, clearly the more there are in circulation the greater the odds of success. With a RP their numbers were greatly reduced. In my case some were left behind as evidenced by positive margins, lymph node involvement, etc. Hopefully those are being killed with IMRT and any swimming around are being starved to death due to the HT (Lupron).

Posts.Title: Psychology today weighs in on Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Georgia Gal, Personally I'm biased toward surgery, even if has to be followed up with Radiation. Post surgery when the Pathologist gets the prostate you know 99% where you stand. For the 1% you can rely on the post-op PSA. At the three month test it should be undetectable and stay there. One thing I want to add was concerning ED. In the worst case if non-nerve sparring surgery is needed, ED is permanent. But orgasms are at least the same with many men on this site reporting an improvement. The "one (maybe two) and you are done" is gone for some reason. There are several ways to deal with the ED but once accomplished sex can be better than before. I would shoot for nerve sparring surgery. For G 3+4 and lower it as been shown to be safe, for G8-G10 the surgeons goes wide and takes it all. G 4+3 is a bit more gray. It sounds like you have a good surgeon and at a great med center, I would go with the surgeon on this one.

Posts.Title: Thoughts on my Hormone Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fishing Larry it's within the margins" does that mean it has spread but just close by? Or what does that exactly mean They dye the removed mass, typically with blue and black dye for the different lobes. It is removed in multiple sections. The organ size and surgical method (open versus RALP) determine the number of sections Once the pathologist gets it they look for cancer that goes right up to the dyed edge. These edges are the margins. If the disease goes right up to the margin it is a positive margin, it is safe to assume the cancer continued on the other side and was left behind. It is considered contained if the margins are negative, that is they are all normal cells. If the margins are positive you will want to know if it was in one place, multiple places, or a lot of places. The Path report will use focal, multi-focal, or extensive. Be sure to request a copy of the Path report. I hope all goes well and everything comes back negative. If it doesn't there are "next steps" that may still hold the chance for a cure. If you review the signatures of other posters here you can get an idea of the timing for the next steps. Note there is typically many months to a year or more before the next step. There is time to make careful educated choices before signing on to a suggested treatment. I write this because a buddies Dr in Colorado started hormone therapy (HT) a week after the catheter was out even though he had a great Path report. The result is he will likely see a low PSA score at the first 3 month check, but will not know if it is a result of the HT or a successful surgery. You can't optimally treat if you do not know what it is.

Posts.Title: Thoughts on my Hormone Treatment

Posts.Content: Hello Hopper, I had de Vinci 11/2013 and I'm biased in favor of this approach. With surgery you get a current picture of your condition. The bulk or all of the disease is out, it's under the pathologist's microscope. They literally see if the cancer went right up to the cut (positive margins), if it did then it is likely there is cancer left on the other side of the cut. Is it 3, 4, or 5. They get a definitive Gleason score. I was 3/4 at biopsy and 4/5 at pathology. They can check the seminal ducts and urethra, and also the few lymph nodes they take. 7 days after surgery when you go back to have the catheter removed they will discuss the pathology report. Given your numbers there is a good chance you will hear they got it all. If they discover positive margins, a higher Gleason score, or other issues you will know. Your 3 month PSA will likely be <.01 and stay there for a long time, possibly indefinitely. If your numbers start creeping up you can have radiation. Once the catheter is out at week you are back doing things. With radiation you have 8 weeks of daily treatments and 2 more before some of the effects really start to tapper off. Your PSA tappers down through treatment and for months after with some bouncing around but never goes to zero. The definition of re-occurrence is in the process of being re-defined but is generally 2 to 3 tests with increasing PSA. The tests are 3 months part. in short, you did not find out specifics about your disease and will have the better part of a year before you get a feeling of where you are at. The past few months have likely been stressful due to the unknown, this will continue for the next year. Finally, you can't have surgery after radiation so that option is gone. I'll address what to to expect in the next post...
Posts.Title: Nervous, 2nd thoughts

Posts.Content: I 2nd Michael F's comment. A NIH study documented outcomes specifically using De Vinci versus surgeon experience and found results level off after 200-300 procedures. My local Doctor had 30 under his belt so I drove 65 miles to a Doctor that had over 1000. I'm glad I did. What to Expect: I was in the hospital one night. Percocet for 3 days (narcotics cause serious constipation) Tylenol for 3 more, and then no pain. The worst experience was the catheter and urine bag. I returned to the hospital a week after surgery and they removed the catheter and the next day day I drove to work for a half day and after a holiday weekend I returned full time with a cushion for the chair (I have a desk job and can stand and walk around). For a physical job figure up to 4 weeks depending how physical. They cut the urethra where it attaches to the bladder since the prostate is around it and re-attach it (yikes) to the bladder so you do not want to chance breaking the plumbing. So no setting on hard surfaces, bicycles, bar stools and keep popping the stool softeners (NO straining down there). Incontinence - I wore the full Depends briefs home after the catheter was removed and found them overkill. A pad in Jockey briefs was enough to contain everything even when an entire bladder escaped a few times during the first few weeks. They fit in a pocket. Laying down I was dry from the first night. After the first month the pads were rarely more than damp and never saturated. Month two, even after a long week installing equipment on an outdoor job site, they were at best damp. By month 3 they were dry and by month 4 I forget them altogether. I went through one package of the heavy ones and 2 of the mediums so about 210 in 100 days. I never had an embarrassing moment and no one ever knew. At month 3 I had my first PSA test. It was <.01 It had crept up to .1 in a year and I'm now on HRT with RT soon to start. With a bad DRE, 10 of 12 cores at 4 some upgraded to 5 post surgery, positive margins everywhere, a few positive lymph nodes it was expected. Because it has remain near zero for a year without HRT they are optimistic I still have a shot at a cure or at least a long remission after RT. As I wrote I expect you will do better. One area I got caught short in was penile rehabilitation. Recent studies have shown using a VED and low dose Viagra or similar will reduce shrinkage and most of it will come back once function return or an implant is used. If you do nothing there will be more loss and it will never come back. If this matter to you talk to the Doctor.

Because it has remain near zero for a year without HRT they are optimistic I still have a shot at a cure or at least a long remission after RT. As I wrote I expect you will do better. One area I got caught short in was penile rehabilitation. Recent studies have shown using a VED and low dose Viagra or similar will reduce shrinkage and most of it will come back once function return or an implant is used. If you do nothing there will be more loss and it will never come back. If this matter to you talk to the Doctor.

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for the good wishes and Jim's idea of a office gift at the end is a good one that I would have missed. The staff is very good to me. Today was #2 of 33, like MartyATX said "ground hog day" except much faster at 8 minutes in and out once my name was called. Wilde - with your numbers you have a good shot at not having to do this or a cure if you do. If I were you I would consider switching to the ultra-sensitive PSA test, just don't do anything rash until you really see a upward trend over several tests. As a G9 with positive everything I'm a poor canary in the coal mine to peg your sleep to, but then again they were surprised I made it a year at 0.1 without HT. I had hoped for the camaraderie among PCa soldiers Creekrat found at his sessions but it isn't happening. It is a large crowd but mostly women with only a few men. All but a couple look like they are fighting an end-game. God bless them.

Posts.Content: I'm following Creekrats lead by logging my adjuvant RT: BIDMC Boston added yet another Varian TrueBeam with all the options which was only commissioned a couple of weeks ago, I'm glad others were first to use it. Here's a pic: http://www.variantruebeam.com/truebe...ian/index.html They had me remove my shoes and sports coat, lay on the bed, and drop my pants and shorts just south of my privates under the sheets. No tube in the bum. The CT panels dropped down and made a quick pass. Since it was visit #1 the RO had to OK the image which added a 5 minutes wait. With a thumbs up from the RO the CT panels retracted and the main head started buzzing. It made a single pass over and under me taking about a minute. I was done. I pulled up my pants, stepped off the bed into my shoes, and got my jacket on the way out the door. Other than a 10 minute near nap I did not feel a thing. I had a nice chat with the RO (Dr J Aronovitz from Barnes and now BIDMC Boston). The plan is 69 GY total in 34 sessions with most in the prostate bed and the rest where the lymph nodes live.

Posts.Title: HMS SRT Log 1 down 33 to go

Posts.Content: Hello Don, I'm sorry to hear of your loss, and now this. As others have posted with a leading G4 and the possibility of localized spread it is something that needs treatment sooner than later. The signatures at the bottom of some of the posts will give you a feeling for the time lines from biopsy to primary and then secondary treatment. You have time to review the options and pick a good medical team. Whether or the not the area of the questionable lymph node is accessible with normal RT is a question for the Radiation oncologist. If it is you may have an option of either approach. Having had a RALP I can say the first 7 days or until the catheter is removed you will need someone even if they are in and out at lot. My wife worked during the day but was 20 minutes away if I had needed something. Bed to bathroom and back with an occasional short slow loop around the house to prevent clots is about it for the first few days. Starting on day 8 without the catheter I visited the office, I could do short errands, short walks, and even made dinner a couple of nights that second week. At G9 I selected RALP, knowing RT would likely follow, for the faster recovery and also to throw everything available at the PC. Plus I wanted to know the details that a pathologist with a microscope could provide, I didn't like them, but Im glad I got them. Were all here to answer question.

Posts.Title: Radiation log

Posts.Content: There are numerous papers (eg; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21036487) and trials where chemo was started early. A study in MA was even looking for high grade at biopsy patients to start chemo and HT pre RP. It is not known if it is an effective strategy but there are trials and research in process.

Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: Here is another related paper. I had already had my RALP before I became aware of a local chemo with ADT pre-RP study. It is likely I would have joined the study if I had been aware of it. For now it looks like they are attempting to determine the risks of this approach and it will be a while before they determine if it is effective.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the additional links. I have been watching this since I came across the following Phase-3 trial that is enrolling patients now: "This randomized study is looking at the benefits of using docetaxel (chemotherapy) added to one of the standard treatments (radiation and hormones) for men with high-risk prostate cancer." http://www.danafarberbostonchildrens...l-details.aspx The Phase 1 and 2 demonstrated safety and benefit.

Posts.Title: Radiation log

Posts.Content: Hello Tom, I started Lupron last Nov and have had a 1 month and two 3 month shots in the bum. I pictured something the size of a BB since it is good for 3 months and being inter-muscular would hurt for days. It is a fairly fine needle, and other than a very small pinch it's painless. I get the hot flashes 2-3 times a day. I'm suddenly hot, mainly shoulders and face. Just as quickly I notice it is gone. There is no ramp up or down. The fatigue is harder to describe. It gets me more on transitions from idle to cruising. If I jump out of my chair and trot up the stairs to the lab I find I'm breathing a bit harder for a minute or two. Same for a walk with the wife. The first 1/4 mile I notice a bit more breathing and faster heart rate but the next 2-3 miles including a good hill I'm normal. I work a long day typically at a desk, week before last I lead a week long equipment change out on a wind farm and was 100% while my buddies were suffering from the altitude. I used to get home late and start a project in the home lab or garage. Now I'm happy to kick back, go for a walk, watch TV, the wife loves it. It is like my initiative is down a notch. I'm not tired, sleepy, sore, or anything. I wonder if lower T has made me less of a conquering warrior? Exercise is up a tick, diet is down, and I have still gained 3-4 pounds. I have no other symptoms.
